segment.source: Building a Driver with the WDK
segment.target: Building a Driver with the WDK

segment.source: This topic describes how you can build a driver with the Windows Driver Kit (WDK).
segment.target: This topic describes how you can build a driver with the Windows Driver Kit (WDK).

segment.source: WDK 10 is fully integrated with Microsoft Visual Studio.
segment.target: WDK 10 is fully integrated with Microsoft Visual Studio.

segment.source: You can build a driver using the Visual Studio development environment, or you can build a driver directly from the command line by using the Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild).
segment.target: You can build a driver using the Visual Studio development environment, or you can build a driver directly from the command line by using the Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild).

segment.source: You can use any edition of Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, including Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2015, to build drivers for:
segment.target: You can use any edition of Microsoft Visual Studio 2015, including Microsoft Visual Studio Community 2015, to build drivers for:

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows 8.1
segment.target: Windows 8.1

segment.source: Windows 7
segment.target: Windows 7

segment.source: Important Starting in Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8, MSBuild replaced the Windows Build Utility (Build.exe).
segment.target: Important Starting in Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8, MSBuild replaced the Windows Build Utility (Build.exe).

segment.source: The WDK now uses the same compiler and build tools that you use to build Visual Studio projects.
segment.target: The WDK now uses the same compiler and build tools that you use to build Visual Studio projects.

segment.source: Driver projects that were built with previous versions of the WDK must be converted to work in the Visual Studio environment.
segment.target: Driver projects that were built with previous versions of the WDK must be converted to work in the Visual Studio environment.

segment.source: You can run a conversion utility from the command line, or you can convert an existing driver by creating new Visual Studio project from existing sources.
segment.target: You can run a conversion utility from the command line, or you can convert an existing driver by creating new Visual Studio project from existing sources.

segment.source: For more info, see Creating a Driver From Existing Source Files and WDK and the Visual Studio build environment.
segment.target: For more info, see Creating a Driver From Existing Source Files and WDK and the Visual Studio build environment.

segment.source: Building a Driver Using Visual Studio
segment.target: Building a Driver Using Visual Studio

segment.source: You build a driver the same way you build any project or solution in Visual Studio.
segment.target: You build a driver the same way you build any project or solution in Visual Studio.

segment.source: When you create a new driver project using a Windows driver template, the template defines a default (active) project configuration and a default (active) solution build configuration.
segment.target: When you create a new driver project using a Windows driver template, the template defines a default (active) project configuration and a default (active) solution build configuration.

segment.source: Note You can convert projects and solutions that you created with WDK 8 or Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8.1 to work with Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 10 and Visual Studio 2015.
segment.target: Note You can convert projects and solutions that you created with WDK 8 or Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 8.1 to work with Windows Driver Kit (WDK) 10 and Visual Studio 2015.

segment.source: Before you open the projects or solutions, run the ProjectUpgradeTool.
segment.target: Before you open the projects or solutions, run the ProjectUpgradeTool.

segment.source: The ProjectUpgradeTool converts the projects and solutions so that they can be built using WDK 10.
segment.target: The ProjectUpgradeTool converts the projects and solutions so that they can be built using WDK 10.

segment.source: For information about managing and editing build configurations, see Building in Visual Studio.
segment.target: For information about managing and editing build configurations, see Building in Visual Studio.

segment.source: The default Solution build configuration is Debug and Win32.
segment.target: The default Solution build configuration is Debug and Win32.

segment.source: In versions of the WDK prior to Windows 8, this build configuration would correspond to building a driver using an x86 Checked Build Environment.
segment.target: In versions of the WDK prior to Windows 8, this build configuration would correspond to building a driver using an x86 Checked Build Environment.

segment.source: To select a configuration and build a driver
segment.target: To select a configuration and build a driver

segment.source: Ensure that you have the same version of SDK and WDK installed on your computer.
segment.target: Ensure that you have the same version of SDK and WDK installed on your computer.

segment.source: Open the driver project or solution in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Open the driver project or solution in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Right-click the solution in the Solutions Explorer and select Configuration Manager.
segment.target: Right-click the solution in the Solutions Explorer and select Configuration Manager.

segment.source: From the Configuration Manager, select the Active Solution Configuration (for example, Debug or Release) and the Active Solution Platform (for example, Win32) that correspond to the type of build you are interested in.
segment.target: From the Configuration Manager, select the Active Solution Configuration (for example, Debug or Release) and the Active Solution Platform (for example, Win32) that correspond to the type of build you are interested in.

segment.source: Select the target operating system for which to build the driver.
segment.target: Select the target operating system for which to build the driver.

segment.source: Navigate to the project properties in Driver > General, and set the TargetVersion property.
segment.target: Navigate to the project properties in Driver > General, and set the TargetVersion property.

segment.source: Configure the project properties for your driver or driver package.
segment.target: Configure the project properties for your driver or driver package.

segment.source: You can set properties for deployment, driver signing, or other tasks.
segment.target: You can set properties for deployment, driver signing, or other tasks.

segment.source: For more information, see Configuring project properties for your driver and driver package.
segment.target: For more information, see Configuring project properties for your driver and driver package.

segment.source: From the Build menu, click Build Solution (Ctrl+Shift+B).
segment.target: From the Build menu, click Build Solution (Ctrl+Shift+B).

segment.source: Building a Driver Using the Command Line (MSBuild)
segment.target: Building a Driver Using the Command Line (MSBuild)

segment.source: You can build a driver from the command line using the Visual Studio Command Prompt window and the Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild)
segment.target: You can build a driver from the command line using the Visual Studio Command Prompt window and the Microsoft Build Engine (MSBuild)

segment.source: To build a driver using the Visual Studio Command Prompt window
segment.target: To build a driver using the Visual Studio Command Prompt window

segment.source: Open a Developer Command Prompt for VS2015 window.
segment.target: Open a Developer Command Prompt for VS2015 window.

segment.source: From this window you can use MSBuild.exe to build any Visual Studio project by specifying the project (.VcxProj) or solutions (.Sln) file.
segment.target: From this window you can use MSBuild.exe to build any Visual Studio project by specifying the project (.VcxProj) or solutions (.Sln) file.

segment.source: Navigate to the project directory and enter the MSbuild command for your target.
segment.target: Navigate to the project directory and enter the MSbuild command for your target.

segment.source: For example, to perform a clean build of a Visual Studio driver project called MyDriver.vcxproj using the default Platform and Configuration, navigate to the project directory and enter the following MSBuild command:
segment.target: For example, to perform a clean build of a Visual Studio driver project called MyDriver.vcxproj using the default Platform and Configuration, navigate to the project directory and enter the following MSBuild command:

segment.source: Syntax - To specify a specific configuration and platform, use the following command syntax:
segment.target: Syntax - To specify a specific configuration and platform, use the following command syntax:

segment.source: For example, the following command builds a Universal Windows driver for the "Debug" configuration, "Win32" platform, and for Windows 10.
segment.target: For example, the following command builds a Universal Windows driver for the "Debug" configuration, "Win32" platform, and for Windows 10.

segment.source: The TargetPlatformVersion setting is optional and allows you to specify the kit version to build with.
segment.target: The TargetPlatformVersion setting is optional and allows you to specify the kit version to build with.

segment.source: The default is to use the latest kit.
segment.target: The default is to use the latest kit.

segment.source: Configuring project properties for your driver and driver package
segment.target: Configuring project properties for your driver and driver package

segment.source: You use property pages to configure and set options for your driver and driver package.
segment.target: You use property pages to configure and set options for your driver and driver package.

segment.source: You can choose to configure your driver so that it is automatically signed when you build your solution, or automatically deployed to a remote test computer.
segment.target: You can choose to configure your driver so that it is automatically signed when you build your solution, or automatically deployed to a remote test computer.

segment.source: The WDK provides a number of command-line tools, such as Stampinf and WPP Preprocessor (WPP Tracing), that are commonly included in the build process.
segment.target: The WDK provides a number of command-line tools, such as Stampinf and WPP Preprocessor (WPP Tracing), that are commonly included in the build process.

segment.source: These tools are not distributed with Visual Studio.
segment.target: These tools are not distributed with Visual Studio.

segment.source: To combine these tools with the Visual Studio build environment they are wrapped as WDK tasks for MSBuild.
segment.target: To combine these tools with the Visual Studio build environment they are wrapped as WDK tasks for MSBuild.

segment.source: If you use one of the driver templates or have an existing driver that you have converted, these property pages might already exist for your project.
segment.target: If you use one of the driver templates or have an existing driver that you have converted, these property pages might already exist for your project.

segment.source: If not, the property pages are automatically added to your project as you add the related file types to the project or solution (for example, .mc or .man files for the message compiler).
segment.target: If not, the property pages are automatically added to your project as you add the related file types to the project or solution (for example, .mc or .man files for the message compiler).

segment.source: For more information, see WDK and the Visual Studio build environment
segment.target: For more information, see WDK and the Visual Studio build environment

segment.source: You can set properties for an individual driver or for an entire driver package.
segment.target: You can set properties for an individual driver or for an entire driver package.

segment.source: The following table shows some of the available properties that you can configure specifically for drivers and driver packages.
segment.target: The following table shows some of the available properties that you can configure specifically for drivers and driver packages.

segment.source: Driver Project Properties
segment.target: Driver Project Properties

segment.source: Driver Package Properties
segment.target: Driver Package Properties

segment.target: Signing properties for individual driver files (see Signing a Driver)

segment.target: Signing properties for driver packages (see Signing a Driver)

segment.target: Deployment Properties for Driver Package Projects (see Deploying a Driver to a Test Computer)

segment.target: Driver Verifier Properties for Driver Package Projects

segment.target: Message Compiler Properties for Driver Projects

segment.target: KMDF Verifier Properties for Driver Package Projects

segment.target: Stampinf Properties for Driver Projects

segment.target: UMDF Verifier Properties for Driver Package Projects

segment.source: Troubleshooting tip for building a driver
segment.target: Troubleshooting tip for building a driver

segment.source: The following tip can help you to troubleshoot problems when you use the WDK and Visual Studio to build drivers.
segment.target: The following tip can help you to troubleshoot problems when you use the WDK and Visual Studio to build drivers.

segment.source: To increase the verbosity of the build output using the options in Visual Studio
segment.target: To increase the verbosity of the build output using the options in Visual Studio

segment.source: Click Tools> Options.
segment.target: Click Tools> Options.

segment.source: Click the Project and Solutions folder and click Build and Run.
segment.target: Click the Project and Solutions folder and click Build and Run.

segment.source: Change the options for the MSBuild project build output verbosity and MSBuild project build log file verbosity.
segment.target: Change the options for the MSBuild project build output verbosity and MSBuild project build log file verbosity.

segment.source: By default, these are set to Minimal.
segment.target: By default, these are set to Minimal.
